Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a 400-MHz NMR Spectrometer to Support Faculty-Student Research and Training at WIU and Partner Institutions
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program that is co-funded by the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) Program, Professor T.K. Vinod from Western Illinois University and colleagues Brian Bellott, Jin Jin, Shaozhong Zhang and Rose McConnell will acquire a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer. The project is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) synthesis and reactions of water-soluble hypervalent iodine reagents; (b) oxidative cleavage of alkenes using an in-situ generated aryliodonium ion with oxone as terminal oxidant; (c) design and development of green oxidation experiments for the classroom activities; (d) synthesis and characterization of cathespsin inhibitors; (e) NMR based equilibrium studies of 13C labeled leupeptin analogues; (f) synthesis of organoselenium antioxidants; (g) quantitative detection of heavy metals using a seleno or telluro fluorescent probe; (h) synthesis and study of tellurium and silicon containing macrocycles; (i) steric and electronic contributions of phosphines in catalytic systems; and (j) synthesis of fulleridophiles.

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research not only at Western Illinois University but also at collaborating institutions such as Quincy University and Carl Sandburg College.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NMR spectrometer acquired through this NSF-MRI grant has been extensively used for research, teaching, training and professional development of the participants and students of Western Illinois University. The primary impact sought and achieved are the instructional activities aimed at introducing the concepts and practice of NMR spectroscopy.  A wide group of undergraduates and graduate students benefitted from the hands-on NMR experience provided through different courses at various levels and in varying depths of coverage. The Organic Spectroscopy course, CHEM 500, for advanced undergraduates and graduate students utilized the instrument to carry out both 1-D and 2-D experiments for structure elucidation of complex organic molecules. The hands-on training that we provide to our students on the newly acquired NMR spectrometer and other instruments in the department allows us to produce qualified and well-trained students.  The instrument is and continue to be extensively used for independent research of all participants. Specific research projects that are enabled by the new instrument include investigations in the areas of synthetic chemistry, medicinal chemistry, organometallic chemistry and material science. The design, development and optimization of ‘Green’ synthetic chemistry experiments for wider adaptation and inclusion in undergraduate laboratory curriculum is another research objective of this MRI proposal. Research findings from these projects have been published and presented at many American Chemical Society meetings by the student participants in research projects. In terms of professional development, both Professors Brian Bellott and Jin Jin are tenure track faculty members who have extensively used the instrument to further their research objectives as they approach their tenure application.  The new instrument is also available for research and training needs faculty members of Quincy University and Carl Sandburg College, two nearby institutions
